metadata.name: Stranded #19
metadata.description:
Is it trying to move? I think I saw it moving, just a bit..
I know it's stranded, but... what is it?


an implementation of Frei Otto's 'Wet Wool' experiment and model
made with p5js and love

metadata.name: Ridge Blur #231
metadata.description:
This work is the second in the ridge series. While using the same base algorithm this work is about exploring landscapes using a much more dark and desolate imagery.

It was designed to be experienced in fullscreen in live mode.
Press "s" to save a screenshot.

Dutch auction (14/11/8), updating every 5min.

Original artwork by William Watkins · Lyon, 2022

metadata.name: Poems in the Public Domain #124
metadata.description:
POEMS IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN [PITPD] represents a new form of poetic anthology—one that celebrates the role of the reader in shaping the life of a poem. In this unique art piece, 14 readers take turns discovering 30 classic poems. We invite collectors to explore this compendium, selected to present a diverse, engaging archive that acknowledges the importance of certain seminal works in shaping our collective unconscious. 

Inspired by Roland Barthe's maxim, "those who fail to reread are obliged to read the same story everywhere," each reader is represented by multiple pen colors & new marginalia, suggesting the crucial act of rereading. 

The verses vanish, just like our memory of their exact words might fade, but distilled, standout moments of personal connection remain. In time, even these wane, providing a scarcely perceptible backdrop as the poem is discovered & interpreted anew. 

PITPD explores authorship. When a poem enters the public domain, it no longer belongs to its author but to its readers. In the intimate moments we read a poem, we link it to our private, pulsating worlds & help ensure others will read it, too. If history’s palms hadn’t held Sappho’s words, our fingers wouldn’t hold them now. 

Readers write poetry’s survival. 

Each iteration of PITPD traces a narrative that can play for hours without repeating. Some 89% of iterations chronicle the life of a single poem, while 11% include multiple poems, intentionally surveying intertextuality. Taking advantage of the generative medium, embodied readership is represented via dynamic handwriting, dancing markings, algorithmic paper aging, coded stains, & other effects.

Spacebar pauses & resumes the animation. Refreshing the browser window restarts it. For those interested in the underlying code, please open the browser console. This collection’s ciphers, too, are in the public domain.

Additional information can be found in the companion article on fx(text): fxhash.xyz/article/poems-in-the-public-domain-marginalia-as-living-verse

metadata.name: Sol #242
metadata.description:
Sol is a companion project that complements my recent series, Metamorphosis. Both projects share a common foundation - a cellular automata engine. The state of each cell in a new generation is influenced by its own state as well as those of its neighboring cells from the last generation. The rules guiding these state transitions, however, are dynamic.

Sol for me is an experimental plotter project. As a gesture of my gratitude to minters of Metamorphosis, all minters will be on the reserve list for a free piece of Sol. I’ll take a snapshot of Metamorphosis for the reserve list 30 minutes prior to Sol’s launch. For three days (unless all reserve-holders mint sooner), Sol will be only for those on the reserve list and I'll add anyone who purchases Metamorphosis on primary subsequently. After this period, any remaining pieces, along with an additional 50 mints, will be available for public sale.

A Note on the Name: The inspiration behind the name 'Sol' springs from my visits to SF MoMA, where I always find myself in the space dedicated to Sol LeWitt. Through the repetition and variation of a singular concept, LeWitt constructed forms that were striking, often evolving from basic geometric forms into intricate structures. The same is also echoed in the principle of emergence in cellular automata, where complex systems arise from the interactions of simple components governed by rules. This series, Sol, is a homage to LeWitt's ingenuity in favoring dispassionate geometric forms over the emotionally-infused abstract art styles.

Implemented in JS, this code utilizes the Perlin.js and Simple-noise.js libraries.

Press p to save a png of the image in full screen. Press s to save a single complete svg file for plotting. To download three separate svg files with individual colors for plotting press 1,2 & 3. Running an optimization tool can help decrease the plotting time.

Pixel Love!

metadata.name: Enlightened Journey #209
metadata.description:
A digital journey through nature.

Made in p5js

Special thanks to @Zancan and @TenebrisVia for inspiring me to code with nature, along with the work of Linda Rous for inspiring the use of perspective and stairs in the scene. Also, thanks to the FX Hash and Twitter communities for the wonderful feedback and suggestions which helped throughout the design process.

metadata.name: RushGushBlush #112
metadata.description:
Let's celebrate #fxhashturnsone with a cascade of colors!

This is just my second release on fxhash and I couldn't be happier to dedicate this project, however simple, to this amazing community.

I could go on describing the details of this piece but honestly I just wanted to create something very colorful for the party, without putting too many hidden meanings! :)
(Or maybe not...)

Happy birthday fxhash!

---

80% of primary sales will be donated to the Processing Foundation and Save Pakistan.

---

There are 17 different palettes and 3 formats, hope you'll find a combination that makes you happy!
The texture might look weird in thumbnails, so I recommend opening the piece in full screen and/or download the png by pressing "s".

---

By Todemashi 2022
NFT License 2.0

### NOTES
Made with p5js.
This project uses fx(stdio) by @alt_escapism - https://altesc.art/stdio

webgl + js

metadata.name: Turbulence #343
metadata.description:
Swirly shapes are rendered by passes of poisson samples of a warped noise field. The noise shifts with each pass, creating a layered effect. 

Dense editions may take over 2 minutes to draw fully.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.

Press ’s’ to save a screenshot. Image size is 928x1200px
Press ’p’ to pause/resume at any time during the drawing.

Add '&size=#' to the end of the live view URL to render a not 1:1 variation of your edition at a resolution up to 3,000 px.

Common:
- 43 set palettes plus many more with combinations
- 3 color distribution methods
- 50/50 dark
- 50/50 monochrome with bright highlights 
- 3 drawing styles: lines, points, colored pencils
- 5 noises effects: full screen, distance from center, distance from bottom, horizontal center, vertical center, random circles, 3,5, or 7 horizontal and vertical bars
- Poisson point distribution based on set layers or the noise value

Rare
- 15% chance of a dark monochrome with gold strands

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.description: Sketches made by an anthropologist based on ancient texts describing the purgatory where lost souls wander.

metadata.name: Automatic #342
metadata.description:
Cellular automata is fascinating :) Applications ranging from physics and biology to modeling and architecture, with artistic and aesthetic representation always following along. Perfect example for emergence, how simple even byte-size rules result in complex structures, forming patterns and unpredictable behaviors...

This one is simple, 1d elementary cellular automata and the 256 rules as the foundation, where each iteration consists of the following elements: base rules - 3 are selected and allocated into the start row compositions, a set of shapes is assigned to a grid of various sizes. Occasionally, dynamic rule set is added - where a rule is randomly transformed into another random rule on a random row of the grid. A vertical or horizontal alignment of the grid is chosen an a color set assigned. Sometimes, a simple 2d noise is applied to lighten (or well, darken) things a bit. The grid is finite and confined by the amount of cells in a row and amount of rows fitting the canvas given cell size.

The properties are recorded as features, more as a reference to the building blocks, rather then rarity indication. Probably be best viewed in live mode :)

Pressing 's' in live mode will save the png of the output.

metadata.name: Proto alphabet #99
metadata.description:
For more than 4000 years, before Lineal A in Crete, proto alphabets were created. They freed man from the chains of evolution and gave a way to record the rhythm of the passage of time.

As recursion generates a grammar, recursion generates the strokes that shape the following proto alphabets, which attempt to record the passage of time.

Time is the substance I am made of. Time is a river which sweeps me along, but I am the river; it is a tiger which destroys me, but I am the tiger; it is a fire which consumes me, but I am the fire. - Jorge Luis Borges


Desde hace más de 4000 años, antes Lineal A en Creta, proto alfabetos fueron creados. Liberaron al hombre de las cadenas de la evolución y dieron una forma para registrar el ritmo del paso del tiempo.

Como la recursividad genera una gramática, la recursividad genera los trazos que dan forma a los siguientes proto alfabetos, los cuales intentan registrar el paso del tiempo.

El tiempo es la sustancia de que estoy hecho. El tiempo es un río que me arrebata, pero yo soy el río; es un tigre que me destroza, pero yo soy el tigre; es un fuego que me consume, pero yo soy el fuego. - Jorge Luis Borges


Controls (in live view):
- Press s to get a PNG file
- Press S to get a SVG file

Artwork by x0y0z0 @x0y0z0tn (2023)

metadata.name: Tree Skyness #221
metadata.description:
Tree Skyness

Crown shyness occurs when the tops of fully grown trees avoid touching each other, forming gaps in the canopy. This piece simulates that phenomena and plays with celestial object avoidance. Features include four seasons, time of day, up to 12 trees, and many special options. HD rendering can be enabled for 8192x8192 resolution. 10% of primary sales will be donated to the fxhash Ukraine fund.

Click to randomize with the same settings.

By Frank Force @KilledByAPixel
Made with Vanilla JavaScript

Controls
1 = Save a 2048x2048 png (or right click save)
2 = Toggle HD (may not work in some environments)
3 = Toggle noise (disable for clearer image)

metadata.name: 밝고 짧게, Brightly and Briefly #7
metadata.description:
Burn, brightly and briefly.
Burn, brightly and briefly.

Remembering our brightest moment, however brief it may have been.

metadata.name: 마음, Heart #3
metadata.description:
Countless points of thoughts and feelings form lines and then shape. Sometimes it is unbearably heavy and sometimes, incredibly light. Even when our heart is full of thoughts and feelings, the emptiness comes without a notice.

The trigonometric function and recursion create repetition and shape while random function and perlin noise gives its randomness and naturalness. Although it may seem ironic to express ‘heart’ with code, such repetition of shapes, randomness, and naturalness resemble our heart.
